concepts.common_misconceptions: Pupils often read values correctly but then choose the wrong operation: for 'how many more', they may add rather than subtract. For two-step questions, pupils may answer only the first step and stop. When totalling all categories, pupils may read an axis value rather than add up all the bars.

prerequisite_relationships.rationale: Year 2 counting in twos directly supports Year 3 counting in fours through the doubling relationship: 4 = 2 × 2, so counting in fours is like counting in twos twice
Counting in fours is a prerequisite for counting in eights because 8 = 4 × 2, so the 8s sequence is the double of the 4s sequence
Year 2 counting in fives supports Year 3 counting in fifties since multiples of 50 are multiples of 5 scaled by 10
Year 2 counting in tens directly supports counting in hundreds (each multiple of 100 is a multiple of 10 scaled by 10)
Year 2 finding 10 more/less with two-digit numbers extends directly to the same operation with three-digit numbers in Year 3
Counting in hundreds prepares pupils to understand 100 more/less as a single step along the hundreds counting sequence
Year 2 place value understanding of tens and ones in two-digit numbers is directly extended to include hundreds in three-digit numbers
Understanding the value of each digit in a three-digit number is the prerequisite for partitioning that number into its component parts
Place value understanding is essential for comparing three-digit numbers — pupils compare hundreds first, then tens, then ones
Comparing and ordering numbers provides the conceptual basis for estimation, which requires judging the relative size of a quantity
Year 2 reading and writing numbers to 100 in words is extended to numbers to 1000 in Year 3
Place value understanding in three-digit numbers is essential for selecting the correct column to add to in mental addition strategies
Mental addition strategies with three-digit numbers inform the parallel subtraction strategies, sharing the same place value understanding
Year 2 introduction to formal columnar addition (with two-digit numbers) is extended to three-digit numbers in Year 3
Correct column alignment in addition depends on understanding that digits in the same column have the same place value
Year 2 introduction to formal columnar subtraction is extended to three-digit numbers with exchanges in Year 3
The ability to estimate numbers is the direct prerequisite for estimating calculation results before computing
Year 2 counting in threes and recognising multiples of 3 is the foundation for learning the 3 times table in Year 3
Year 2 knowledge of the 2 times table supports learning the 4 times table in Year 3 through the doubling relationship
The 4 times table is the direct prerequisite for the 8 times table through doubling
All three tables (2, 4, 8) must be known before their doubling connections can be fully understood
Knowledge of the 4 times table is required to understand and apply the doubling connection to the 8 times table
Knowledge of the 8 times table is required to verify the doubling connection with the 4 times table
Times table knowledge is essential for computing the partial products in two-digit by one-digit multiplication
Partitioning two-digit numbers into tens and ones is the core strategy for mental and written multiplication methods
Scaling problems require multiplication skills; knowing how to multiply a two-digit number by a one-digit number enables pupils to solve scaling problems
Correspondence problems are solved by multiplication, so multiplication skill is a prerequisite for the most efficient solution strategy
Year 2 understanding of simple fractions (halves, quarters) provides the conceptual basis for extending to tenths
Year 2 unit fractions (halves, thirds, quarters) are directly extended to a wider range of unit fractions in Year 3
Understanding unit fractions is essential before non-unit fractions, as non-unit fractions are multiples of the unit fraction with the same denominator
Understanding non-unit fractions is needed to recognise that different non-unit fractions can represent the same value (equivalence)
Understanding fractions as collections of equal parts is required before pupils can understand adding same-denominator fractions as combining those parts
Comparing unit fractions requires understanding of unit fractions and the inverse relationship between denominator size and fraction size
Year 2 measurement skills in standard units (cm, m, g, kg, ml, l) are extended in Year 3 to include mm and mixed units
Accurate length measurement skills are a prerequisite for measuring the sides of shapes in order to calculate perimeter
Adding the side lengths to find perimeter requires the mental or written addition skills developed in the number domain
Year 2 simple money calculations extend to mixed £ and p notation and giving change in Year 3
Year 2 telling time to the nearest 5 minutes is extended to the nearest minute and to Roman numeral clocks in Year 3
Fluent reading of 12-hour time is a prerequisite for converting to and from 24-hour notation
Accurately reading start and end times is prerequisite for calculating the duration between them
Year 2 recognition and description of 2-D and 3-D shapes provides the conceptual basis for drawing and constructing them accurately in Year 3
Year 2 work on turns (quarter turn, half turn) provides the experiential basis for formally understanding angles as measures of turn in Year 3
Understanding angles as turns is prerequisite for identifying and comparing right angles, since a right angle is defined as a quarter turn
Understanding right angles is essential for identifying perpendicular lines (which meet at right angles) and thus for distinguishing perpendicular from parallel
Year 2 work with simple bar charts and pictograms (scale of 1) is extended to scaled charts in Year 3
Reading scaled charts accurately is prerequisite for extracting the data values needed to answer one-step and two-step questions
Two-step data questions require performing addition or subtraction on values read from charts, so calculation skill is a prerequisite
